misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No clear notional-machine misconception (correct in-place right-rotation mental model)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to right-shift (rotate) an array by one, you must (1) save the last element, (2) copy each element one index to the right starting from the end to avoid overwriting, and (3) put the saved last element into index 0; then print the array explicitly.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There isn’t an apparent gap here—the code matches Java’s execution model: array assignments happen immediately, copying from right-to-left prevents losing values, and printing requires explicit iteration. The student also correctly guards against n == 0 before accessing arr[n-1].
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None; the program should compile and produce the expected output for typical inputs.
